verses.text: Accept anyone who is weak in faith, but not for passing judgment on disputable opinions.
verses.comment: Paul instructs the community to welcome fellow believers who may be struggling with doubts or weaker consciences, without seeking to argue over non-essential matters. This shows the importance of unity and charity in the life of the church.

verses.text: One person believes he may eat anything, while another, whose faith is weak, eats only vegetables.
verses.comment: Paul addresses early Christian concerns about food, especially regarding dietary laws. Those of stronger faith recognize their freedom; those who are more cautious restrict themselves. Both positions are to be respected.

verses.text: Let the one who eats not look down on the one who does not, and let the one who does not eat not judge the one who eats, for God has accepted them.
verses.comment: Neither judgment nor contempt is acceptable; God is the one who welcomes each believer. Charity and humility are emphasized, echoing Jesus’ own teachings on not judging others (Matt. 7:1).

verses.text: Who are you to judge another’s servant? It is before his own master that he stands or falls. And he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
verses.comment: Paul reminds believers of God’s sovereignty: only the master (God) can judge his servant. This imagery affirms the close relationship between the believer and God, and that God’s grace upholds them.

verses.text: One person considers one day more sacred than another; another considers every day alike. Each one should be fully convinced in his own mind.
verses.comment: Differences regarding holy days are permitted, provided each person acts according to their conscience. This establishes a principle of personal conviction guided by faith and the broader tradition of the community.

verses.text: Whoever observes the day, observes it for the Lord. Whoever eats, eats for the Lord, since he gives thanks to God; and whoever abstains, abstains for the Lord, and gives thanks to God.
verses.comment: Whether participating or abstaining, the believer’s motive should be to honor the Lord. Giving thanks shows the importance of gratitude in all acts of worship and daily living.

verses.text: For none of us lives to himself, and none of us dies to himself.
verses.comment: Life and death find their meaning and purpose in God, not in isolation. The Christian belongs to a larger body and to the Lord.

verses.text: If we live, we live for the Lord, and if we die, we die for the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord’s.
verses.comment: Paul expresses the total belonging of the Christian to the Lord, in both life and death. This reflects the profound union believers have with Christ, echoing themes of self-giving and devotion.

verses.text: For to this end Christ died and lived again, that he might be Lord both of the dead and of the living.
verses.comment: Christ’s death and resurrection establish His lordship over all. This also points to the resurrection hope for all who are united with Him, and the unbroken continuity of the Christian community across time and eternity.

verses.text: But you, why do you judge your brother? Or you, why do you despise your brother? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
verses.comment: Believers are urged to humility, recognizing that God alone is judge. The reference to the judgment seat reminds of ultimate accountability.

verses.text: For it is written: "As I live, says the Lord, every knee shall bow to me, and every tongue shall confess to God."
verses.comment: Paul quotes Isaiah, showing that all will recognize God’s authority. This Old Testament citation emphasizes the divine lordship of Christ (cf. Phil. 2:10-11).

verses.text: So then each of us will give an account of himself to God.
verses.comment: We are each personally responsible before God, calling for examination of conscience and sincere repentance where needed. This anticipates practices of confession and accountability.

verses.text: Therefore let us not judge one another any longer, but rather resolve never to put a stumbling block or obstacle in the way of a brother.
verses.comment: Instead of judging, we ought to consider how our actions affect the faith of others. This echoes Christ’s injunction not to cause ‘little ones’ to stumble (Matt. 18:6).

verses.text: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself, but to the one who considers something to be unclean, for that person it is unclean.
verses.comment: Paul confirms Christian freedom from Old Testament dietary laws (cf. Mark 7:19), but also upholds respect for personal conscience.

verses.text: For if your brother is grieved by what you eat, you are no longer walking according to love. Do not destroy by your food the one for whom Christ died.
verses.comment: Christian liberty is always subordinate to charity. The principle of sacrificial love is to guide interactions—mirroring Christ’s own sacrifice.

verses.text: So do not let what you regard as good be spoken of as evil.
verses.comment: Paul encourages believers to maintain a good witness before others and not abuse their freedom in ways that cause scandal.

verses.text: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of eating and drinking, but of righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: The essence of the Christian life is spiritual, not merely legal or external. Life in the Spirit finds expression in virtue, peace, and joy—central marks of belonging to God’s people and being sanctified.

verses.text: Whoever serves Christ in this way is pleasing to God and approved by men.
verses.comment: Service to Christ, characterized by Spirit-led living, aligns the believer with the will of God and draws approval from others. This echoes Jesus’ teaching about letting your light shine before men (Matt. 5:16).

verses.text: So then, let us pursue what leads to peace and to mutual building up.
verses.comment: The call to foster peace and edify one another is a key vocational mark of the Christian community. The structure reflects the church’s ongoing call to unity and upbuilding.

verses.text: Do not destroy the work of God for the sake of food. Everything is indeed clean, but it is wrong for a person to make another stumble by what he eats.
verses.comment: Paul again affirms Christian freedom but balances it with responsibility for others’ spiritual welfare. The importance of caring for the faith of others is a foundational theme.

verses.text: It is good not to eat meat or drink wine or do anything that causes your brother to stumble.
verses.comment: Charity sometimes calls for self-denial for the sake of another’s conscience—a pattern set by Christ Himself.

verses.text: The faith that you have, keep between yourself and God. Blessed is the one who does not condemn himself by what he approves.
verses.comment: Private conviction guided by an informed conscience is commended, provided it does not contradict revealed truth. The well-formed conscience is central to spiritual maturity.

verses.text: But the one who doubts is condemned if he eats, because his eating is not from faith; for whatever does not proceed from faith is sin.
verses.comment: Acting against one's conscience is sinful. Living by faith—informed by the Church, Scripture, and reason—is essential. This verse highlights how faith and works are deeply connected in the Christian life.
